The story is quite simple: After witnessing the suicide of the father, a sister and her brother must make their way throughout the Australian outback and try to find their way home.
With his help, they are able to survive and trek across the Outback.

Originally released in 1971, this film is characterized by great cinematography of the Australian outback and the rather strange story of a lost English teenage girl and her little brother who are helped to survive by a 16.
The girl, played by Jenny Agutter, is steeped in the ways of civilization and always distrustful of the aboriginal boy, played by David Gulpilil.

The younger boy, played by Luc Roeg, is the son of the director, Nicolas Roeg, and does a fine job of bridging the gap between the two older teenagers as he learns some basic hunting skills and finds ways to communicate with the older boy.

Nicolas Roeg's 1971 masterpiece transcends time and place.
On one level, it's a harrowing adventure of two abandoned kids in the Australian outback.
On another, it's a mystical meditation, a tone poem if you will, about the greater world just beyond our so. called modern civilization.
It's also a wonderful coming of age drama, a love story and an exploration of innocence lost .
There's a mythic sensibility to this enterprise.
beautiful Jenny Agutter was only 16 when production began.

beautifully photographed, this was cinematographer Roeg's directorial debut.
His first feature film explores startling primeval locations in which no white person had trespassed.

This is one of my favorite movies: the panoramas and vistas are extraordinary, the story (to me) is perfectly suited to the cinematography.
Jenny Agutter does an excellent job as the naive Aussie girl trying to protect her brother and survive in a very hostile environment.
The young Aborigine is the perfect foil to her naivete.
I wish it had had at least some subtitles to understand his speech, but I felt his actions spoke beautifully for him.
Some friends think it's a bit slow developing, but I found I liked it.
The situations are appropriate to the storyline.
Roeg showed his talent well with this movie, nearly 40 years ago, and I find it just as interesting today.

I:10199;427;Jenny Agutter (Logan's Run, An American Werewolf In London), on the verge of rising to become one of the finest British actresses of her time, gives a very believable performance as the schoolgirl put in a desperate situation.

I:10199;429;The bonding between the young boy and the aboriginal teen is kind of overshadowed, but there is some striking imagery when these two are together.
I:10199;430;Nicholas Roeg struck pure cinematic gold, when he found David Gulpilil (credited as David Gumpilil), for the critical role as the aboriginal boy.
I:10199;431;Without Gulpilil's performance, one wonders what kind of film Walkabout would have been.
